A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.
A proper ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a prime ideal if for elements $a, b \in R$, $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ implies $a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$.
Does the concept of a/an Integral Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Prime Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a prime ideal does not inherently require the ring $R$ to be an integral domain. A prime ideal is defined for any ring $R$, not specifically for integral domains. The definition of a prime ideal only requires that $R$ be a ring and that the ideal $\\mathfrak{p}$ satisfies the condition that if $ab \\in \\mathfrak{p}$, then either $a \\in \\mathfrak{p}$ or $b \\in \\mathfrak{p}$. This definition is applicable to any ring, whether or not it is an integral domain. Integral domains are a specific type of ring that are commutative, nonzero, and have no nontrivial zero divisors, but these properties are not necessary for the definition of a prime ideal. Therefore, the concept of an integral domain is not necessary for the definition of a prime ideal to make sense.
